1.name: Awareness
1.description: You recognize that your environment and habits shape your life
capabilities: Understand the compound effect of small choices
1.milestone: Complete a 24-hour audit of how you spend time

2.name: Declutterer
capabilities: Identify possessions that don't add value
2.milestone: Declutter one major area of your life (physical space, digital, commitments)

3.name: Routine Builder
3.milestone: Maintain morning and evening routines for 30 days

4.name: Environment Designer
4.description: Intentionally designing spaces for desired behaviors
4.milestone: Redesign one environment to support a key behavior change

6.name: Digital Minimalist
capabilities: Replace low-quality digital with high-quality analog
6.milestone: Achieve intentional technology use with clear boundaries

7.name: Lifestyle Architect
7.description: Designing life around your values and goals
capabilities: Build supportive relationships into life design
7.milestone: Create and follow a complete life design document

8.name: Freedom Designer
8.description: Creating genuine freedom through intentional design
capabilities: Create optionality in all life areas
8.milestone: Have significant flexibility in when/where/how you work

9.name: Life Artist
9.description: Living as a continuous creative project
capabilities: Optimize life experiences not just productivity
9.milestone: Life feels like a creative expression rather than a routine

10.name: Lifestyle Master
10.description: Complete intentionality in all life design
capabilities: Perfect alignment between values and actions
10.milestone: Others seek your guidance on life design

beginner.title: Environment Trigger Audit
beginner.instructions: Walk through your home/workspace. For each area, note: What behavior does this trigger? Is that serving me? Identify 3 changes that would make good behaviors easier.
beginner.success_criteria: Completed audit with 3 actionable environment changes

beginner.title: Digital Detox Day
beginner.instructions: Spend one full day without social media. Put phone in drawer except for essential calls. Notice: What urges arise? What do you do instead? How do you feel at end of day?
beginner.success_criteria: Complete 24 hours without social media with written reflection

beginner.title: Time Allocation Reality Check
beginner.instructions: Track yesterday's time in 30-minute blocks. Categorize: Essential, Valuable, Neutral, Wasteful. Calculate percentages. What's one change you could make?
beginner.success_criteria: Complete time categorization with one specific change identified

intermediate.title: Design Your Ideal Day
intermediate.instructions: Write out your ideal ordinary day (not vacation). Include: Wake time, routines, work blocks, meals, relationships, recovery, sleep. Now identify the biggest gaps between ideal and current.
intermediate.success_criteria: Written ideal day template with gap analysis

intermediate.title: Fear-Setting for Life Change
intermediate.instructions: Pick one lifestyle change you've been considering but haven't made. Use Tim Ferriss's fear-setting: Define worst case, prevent/repair strategies, and cost of inaction. Make a decision.
intermediate.success_criteria: Complete fear-setting worksheet with committed decision

intermediate.title: Environment Design Sprint
intermediate.instructions: Pick one behavior you want to change. Design your environment to make it automatic: Visual cues, reduced friction for good behavior, increased friction for bad. Implement immediately.
intermediate.success_criteria: One environment fully redesigned for target behavior

advanced.title: Complete Life Audit
advanced.instructions: Rate satisfaction (1-10) in each area: Health, Relationships, Work, Finance, Fun, Environment, Personal Growth. For each low score, identify root cause and one action. Create 90-day improvement plan.
advanced.success_criteria: Full life audit with 90-day action plan

advanced.title: Commitment Purge
advanced.instructions: List every recurring commitment (subscriptions, meetings, obligations, relationships). For each, ask: If I wasn't already doing this, would I start? Eliminate at least 3 that fail the test.

advanced.title: Life Operating System Design
advanced.instructions: Document your complete Life OS: Core values, life goals, annual/quarterly/weekly/daily systems, decision frameworks, review cadences. Create a manual for living your ideal life.
advanced.success_criteria: Complete written Life Operating System document

cross_module_connections.insight: Environment beats willpower every time - design for productivity rather than relying on discipline
cross_module_connections.combined_exercise: Redesign your workspace to make your most important work frictionless and distractions friction-full.

cross_module_connections.insight: Lifestyle design determines health outcomes - your environment makes health easy or hard
cross_module_connections.combined_exercise: Stock your kitchen with only foods you want to eat. Remove the decision-making that leads to bad choices.

cross_module_connections.insight: Your physical environment reflects and reinforces your mental state - clutter outside, clutter inside
cross_module_connections.combined_exercise: Declutter one space completely. Notice how it affects your mental clarity and stress levels.

cross_module_connections.insight: Lifestyle inflation is the enemy of freedom - design a life that doesn't require ever-increasing income
cross_module_connections.combined_exercise: Calculate your 'enough' number. Design a lifestyle that's fulfilling at that level, not chasing more.

masters.name: Tim Ferriss
key_principles: The goal is not to simply eliminate the bad, but to pursue and experience the best.
Life doesn't have to be so hard. Most people choose to make it hard.
What we fear doing most is usually what we most need to do.
Being busy is a form of laziness—lazy thinking and indiscriminate action.
Focus on being productive instead of busy.
People will choose unhappiness over uncertainty.
daily_practices: Define the worst case—it's usually not that bad
Design your ideal day, then engineer it

worked_examples.title: Fear-Setting to Enable Life Change
worked_examples.scenario: You want to make a big life change (quit job, move cities, start business) but fear keeps you stuck.
step_by_step: Define: What's the absolute worst case if you do this?
Prevent: What could you do to decrease the likelihood of each worst case?
Repair: If the worst happened, how could you get back to where you are now?
Benefits: What are the potential positive outcomes?
Cost of Inaction: What will your life look like in 6 months, 1 year, 3 years if you don't act?
Comparison: Is the cost of trying less than the cost of not trying?
The answer is usually: the downside is manageable and the cost of inaction is high
worked_examples.outcome: Fear becomes actionable by making it specific and planning for it. Most fears shrink when examined closely.

scripts_templates.title: Fear-Setting Worksheet
scripts_templates.context: Use before any major life decision where fear is holding you back
scripts_templates.template:
WHAT I WANT TO DO BUT FEAR:
___

DEFINE THE WORST CASE (be specific):
1. ___
2. ___
3. ___

PREVENT - How could I prevent or minimize each?
1. ___
2. ___
3. ___

REPAIR - If worst case happened, how could I fix it?
1. ___
2. ___
3. ___

BENEFITS - What are potential positive outcomes?
1. ___
2. ___
3. ___

COST OF INACTION:
6 months from now: ___
1 year from now: ___
3 years from now: ___

DECISION: ___
scripts_templates.example_filled:
WHAT I FEAR: Quitting my job to travel for 6 months

WORST CASE:
1. Run out of money faster than expected
2. Can't find a job when I return
3. Miss out on promotion opportunity

PREVENT:
1. Budget conservatively, have 9 months of expenses saved
2. Stay connected with network, do some freelance while traveling
3. I've already been passed over twice - this promotion isn't guaranteed anyway

REPAIR:
1. I have skills - could freelance or get a job within 2-3 months
2. The gap year is common now, could frame it as intentional growth
3. If I'm valuable enough, companies will want me; if not, I should leave anyway

BENEFITS:
1. See places I've dreamed about my whole life
2. Clarity on what I actually want
3. Break from burnout, come back energized

COST OF INACTION:
6 months: Still fantasizing about travel while resentful at work
1 year: More burned out, watching others do what I want to do
3 years: Full regret, probably more stuck than now

DECISION: Do it. The downside is manageable. The upside is life-changing. The cost of inaction is high.

scripts_templates.title: Ideal Day Design Template
scripts_templates.context: Design your perfect ordinary day as a template for life design
scripts_templates.template:
MY IDEAL ORDINARY DAY:
(Not a vacation day - a regular day you'd be happy to repeat)

MORNING RITUAL (wake to work):
Wake: ___
First 30 min: ___
Exercise/Movement: ___
Morning fuel: ___

PRODUCTIVE HOURS:
Deep work block 1: ___ to ___
Break: ___
Deep work block 2: ___ to ___

MIDDAY:
Lunch: ___
Recovery: ___

AFTERNOON:
Admin/shallow work: ___ to ___
Creative/learning time: ___

EVENING:
End of work: ___
Relationships: ___
Personal enjoyment: ___

NIGHT:
Wind down: ___
Sleep: ___

NON-NEGOTIABLES FOR THIS DAY:
1. ___
2. ___
3. ___

CURRENT GAPS:
___

FIRST CHANGE TO MAKE:
___
scripts_templates.example_filled:
IDEAL DAY:

MORNING:
Wake: 6:00am naturally (no alarm)
First 30 min: Coffee on balcony, journaling
Movement: 45 min workout or run
Fuel: High-protein breakfast

PRODUCTIVE:
Deep work 1: 8:00-11:00 (3 hours creative work)
Break: Walk, no phone
Deep work 2: 11:30-1:00 (strategic/planning work)

MIDDAY:
Lunch: Healthy meal, maybe with a friend
Recovery: 20 min nap or meditation

AFTERNOON:
Admin: 2:00-3:30 (emails, calls, shallow work)
Learning: 4:00-5:00 (reading, course, skill-building)

EVENING:
End work: 5:00 hard stop
Relationships: Dinner with partner, call family
Enjoyment: 1 hour hobby (guitar, reading fiction)

NIGHT:
Wind down: 9:00 (no screens, reading)
Sleep: 10:00

NON-NEGOTIABLES:
1. 3+ hours deep work before any admin
2. Hard stop at 5pm
3. No phone first hour, last hour of day

CURRENT GAPS:
- Wake at 7, rushed morning
- No protected deep work time
- Work bleeds into evening

FIRST CHANGE:
Move wake time to 6:30, protect 8-10am for deep work

books.title: The 4-Hour Workweek
books.author: Tim Ferriss
books.key_takeaway: Escape 9-5, live anywhere, join the new rich through lifestyle design

masters.name: Essentialism (Greg McKeown)
masters.expertise: Less but better, disciplined pursuit of less
key_principles: Less but better.
If it isn't a clear yes, then it's a clear no.
Essentialism is not about how to get more things done; it's about how to get the right things done.
The pursuit of success can be a catalyst for failure.
You cannot overestimate the unimportance of practically everything.
If you don't prioritize your life, someone else will.
daily_practices: Say no to anything that isn't essential
Create space to think and reflect

worked_examples.title: The Essentialist Decision Filter
worked_examples.scenario: You're overwhelmed with opportunities and requests, saying yes to everything.
worked_examples.framework_applied: 90% Rule + Clear Yes or Clear No
step_by_step: For each opportunity, ask: Is this a clear YES?
If you're not 90%+ enthusiastic, it's a no
Write down what you'd have to sacrifice to say yes
Ask: What's the tradeoff? What won't get done?
Remember: Every yes is a no to something else
Create a 'Not To-Do List' - things you've committed to NOT doing
The goal is to do less, better - not more, worse
worked_examples.outcome: Your time goes to vital few activities instead of trivial many. Quality of life and output dramatically increases.

scripts_templates.title: The Essential Decision Matrix
scripts_templates.context: Use to evaluate any opportunity or commitment
scripts_templates.template:
OPPORTUNITY: ___

90% TEST: Am I 90%+ excited about this?
[ ] Yes → Consider it
[ ] No → Decline

IF CONSIDERING:

What would I have to give up to do this well?
___

Is this the very best use of my time?
[ ] Yes [ ] No

If I didn't already have this commitment, would I take it on?
[ ] Yes [ ] No

What is the opportunity cost? (What vital thing won't get done?)
___

DECISION: ___

HOW TO SAY NO (if declining):
'Thank you for thinking of me. This isn't the right fit right now, but I appreciate the opportunity.'
scripts_templates.example_filled:
OPPORTUNITY: Serve on industry advisory board

90% TEST: 70% excited - interesting but not essential
[x] No → Decline

IF CONSIDERING:
Would give up: 10 hrs/month of creative work time
Best use of time: No - my book project is the priority
Would I take it on: Probably not - it's nice for ego but not essential
Opportunity cost: Slower progress on book, which is my #1 goal

DECISION: Decline gracefully

SCRIPT: 'I'm honored you thought of me for this. I'm currently focused on a major project that needs my full attention. I'd love to stay connected for future opportunities when my bandwidth allows.'

books.title: Essentialism: The Disciplined Pursuit of Less
books.author: Greg McKeown
books.key_takeaway: Systematically eliminate the non-essential to focus on what matters

books.title: Effortless
books.author: Greg McKeown
books.key_takeaway: Make the essential things easier to do

podcasts.title: Greg McKeown's Podcast
podcasts.key_takeaway: Ongoing exploration of essentialism in practice

masters.name: Marie Kondo
key_principles: The space in which we live should be for the person we are becoming now.
Keep only those things that speak to the heart and discard items that no longer spark joy.
Tidying is a celebration, a grand send-off for those things that served their purpose.
When you put your house in order, you put your affairs and your past in order too.
The question of what you want to own is actually the question of how you want to live your life.
Life truly begins after you have put your house in order.
daily_practices: Before buying, ask: Does this spark joy?
Return everything to its home after use
Regularly purge what no longer serves you

worked_examples.title: The KonMari Method Applied
worked_examples.scenario: Your space is cluttered with years of accumulated stuff, causing background stress.
step_by_step: Commit completely: This is a one-time event, not ongoing tidying
Declutter by category, not location: All clothes together, all books together, etc.
Order of categories: Clothes → Books → Papers → Miscellaneous → Sentimental
For each item, hold it and ask: Does this spark joy?
If no joy, thank it and let it go
Designate a home for everything that stays
The result: You're surrounded only by things you love
worked_examples.outcome: Your space transforms from cluttered to curated. You feel lighter, clearer, and the environment supports who you want to become.

scripts_templates.title: Spark Joy Decision Framework
scripts_templates.context: Use for every possession and potential purchase
scripts_templates.template:
FOR EXISTING ITEMS:
1. Pick up the item
2. Ask: Does this spark joy?
3. If YES: Keep it, designate a home for it
4. If NO: Thank it for its service, let it go

FOR PURCHASES:
1. Before buying, ask: Does this spark joy?
2. Do I already own something that serves this purpose?
3. Where will this live in my space?
4. Am I buying this for who I am, or who I want to be?

CATEGORY CHECKLIST:
[ ] Clothes - Keep only what makes you feel confident
[ ] Books - Keep only unread essentials and true favorites
[ ] Papers - Digitize or discard almost everything
[ ] Miscellaneous - Be ruthless; most aren't essential
[ ] Sentimental - Save for last; keep only what truly matters
scripts_templates.example_filled:
ITEM: Conference t-shirts (12 of them)

Spark joy? No - I never wear them, they sit in a drawer
Why have I kept them? Guilt, memories of events
Thank them: 'Thank you for reminding me of those experiences'
Decision: Keep 2 meaningful ones, donate the rest

Result: Drawer now has space for clothes I actually wear

books.title: The Life-Changing Magic of Tidying Up
books.author: Marie Kondo
books.key_takeaway: The Japanese art of decluttering and organizing

podcasts.title: Tidying Up with Marie Kondo (Netflix)
podcasts.key_takeaway: Visual demonstration of the KonMari method

masters.name: James Clear (on environment)
key_principles: Environment is the invisible hand that shapes behavior.
Make the cues of good habits obvious in your environment.
Reduce the friction associated with good behaviors.
Increase the friction associated with bad behaviors.
People often choose products not because of what they are, but because of where they are.
Redesign your environment rather than relying on willpower.

worked_examples.title: Environment Design for Behavior Change
worked_examples.scenario: You want to read more but spend evenings scrolling your phone instead.
step_by_step: Identify the bad behavior: Phone scrolling in the evening
Add friction: Put phone in a different room after 7pm, delete apps
Identify the good behavior: Reading
Remove friction: Put book on couch where you sit, have good lighting ready
Add cue: Place book where you'd normally reach for phone
Prime the environment: Each night, set up for the next day
The behavior shift happens because you've made the right choice the easy choice
worked_examples.outcome: Reading becomes the default because it's what's available. Phone scrolling requires effort. Behavior changes without willpower.

scripts_templates.title: Environment Design Audit
scripts_templates.context: Systematically design your space for desired behaviors
scripts_templates.template:
BEHAVIOR I WANT: ___

CURRENT ENVIRONMENT:
- What cues trigger the opposite behavior?
- What friction prevents the desired behavior?
- What's the default option in my space?

ENVIRONMENT REDESIGN:

MAKE IT OBVIOUS:
- How can I add cues for the desired behavior?
- Where can I place reminders?

MAKE IT EASY:
- How can I reduce friction to 0-1 steps?
- Can I prepare in advance?

FRICTION FOR BAD BEHAVIOR:
- How can I add steps to the unwanted behavior?
- Can I remove cues entirely?

SPECIFIC CHANGES:
1. ___
2. ___
3. ___
scripts_templates.example_filled:
BEHAVIOR I WANT: Work out every morning

CURRENT ENVIRONMENT:
- Cues for opposite: Comfortable bed, no workout clothes visible
- Friction: Workout clothes in closet, have to find equipment
- Default: Hit snooze, stay in bed

ENVIRONMENT REDESIGN:

MAKE IT OBVIOUS:
- Lay workout clothes next to bed night before
- Put gym bag by door
- Set multiple alarms

MAKE IT EASY:
- Sleep in workout clothes
- Have water bottle filled
- Equipment laid out

FRICTION FOR BAD:
- Alarm across the room
- No phone within reach at night

SPECIFIC CHANGES:
1. Lay out workout clothes before bed (do tonight)
2. Move phone charger to desk across room
3. Put resistance bands on doorknob as visual cue

books.title: Atomic Habits
books.author: James Clear
books.key_takeaway: The chapter on environment design is particularly powerful for lifestyle change

podcasts.title: James Clear on Tim Ferriss
podcasts.key_takeaway: Deep dive on environment design and behavior change

masters.name: Cal Newport (on digital life)
key_principles: Digital minimalism: A philosophy of technology use based on understanding the value of each tool.
The key is to see solitude as a positive state—not loneliness but a gift.
The cost of a thing is the amount of life you exchange for it.
Clutter is the enemy of clarity.
High-quality leisure beats digital distraction every time.
Reclaim your attention as your most valuable resource.
daily_practices: No phone for first and last hour of day
Schedule social media, don't react to it
Replace low-quality digital with high-quality analog

worked_examples.title: Digital Declutter Sprint
worked_examples.scenario: You realize you spend 4+ hours daily on your phone, mostly on low-value activities.
step_by_step: Commit: 30 days without optional technology (social media, news, streaming)
Define optional: What's genuinely required for work/life? Keep only that.
Rediscover analog: List 20 high-quality leisure activities (reading, hobbies, in-person time)
During 30 days: When urge to check phone arises, do analog activity instead
Week 1-2: Uncomfortable, lots of urges, lots of time
Week 3-4: New habits form, appreciate analog pleasures
Day 31: Reintroduce technology consciously, one by one, with clear rules
worked_examples.outcome: You realize most digital activity added nothing. You return only to tools that genuinely serve your values.

scripts_templates.title: Technology Rules Framework
scripts_templates.context: Set intentional rules for each technology in your life
scripts_templates.template:
FOR EACH TECHNOLOGY, ANSWER:

TOOL: ___

1. Does this tool genuinely support something I deeply value?
Value it supports: ___

2. Is this the best way to support that value?
[ ] Yes - keep with rules
[ ] No - eliminate or replace

3. What specific rules will govern my use?
- When: ___
- Where: ___
- How long: ___
- What for: ___

4. What will I do instead when I get the urge?
___

EVALUATE MONTHLY: Is this serving me or am I serving it?
scripts_templates.example_filled:
TOOL: Twitter/X

1. Does it support something I value? Partially - staying informed in my industry
Value: Professional learning and connection

2. Is it the best way? No - most of my time is scrolling, not learning
Decision: Keep with strict rules

3. Rules:
- When: Only during lunch break (12-12:30pm)
- Where: Only on desktop, not phone
- How long: 30 minutes maximum, timer set
- What for: Only following 50 high-value accounts

4. When I get the urge (outside lunch): Open my Kindle app instead

MONTHLY CHECK: Delete if I'm still scrolling mindlessly even with rules

books.title: Digital Minimalism
books.author: Cal Newport
books.key_takeaway: Choosing a focused life in a noisy world

books.title: Deep Work
books.author: Cal Newport
books.key_takeaway: The relationship between digital distraction and focus

podcasts.title: Deep Questions Podcast
podcasts.key_takeaway: Weekly advice on digital minimalism and the deep life

daily_insights: Your environment shapes your behavior more than your willpower.
Saying no to good things lets you say yes to great things.
Every item you own owns a piece of your attention.
Design your space for who you want to become, not who you were.
The phone is the greatest distraction device ever invented. Control it.
Friction is the difference between what you should do and what you actually do.
Clutter is postponed decisions. Make them now.
Your morning routine is your day in miniature. Design it with intention.
The cost of everything is the life you exchange for it.
Less options, better outcomes. Constrain to liberate.
skill_challenges: Remove one item from your environment that tempts bad behavior.
Make one good habit more obvious (put workout clothes by bed, etc.).
Go 24 hours without social media. Notice the urges.
Declutter one drawer, shelf, or area completely.
Design your ideal morning routine on paper. Try it tomorrow.
Identify your biggest distraction. Add friction to access it.
Unsubscribe from 10 emails that don't add value.
Set up your workspace for deep focus. Remove all distractions.
Delete one app that wastes your time.
Audit your last 24 hours. How much was intentional vs reactive?
